Description: Glazed composition amuletic figure, rather crudely executed, in the form of a cynocephalus standing on a rectangular base, with a squarish suspension ring projecting at the back, at the level of the chest. The glaze is light brown with reddish patches. Notches incised on the chest indicate the fur.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, North-west Ptolemaic mound ?
Curator's comments: Most probably one of the 5 "monkeys" among the "glazed pottery amulets of late work, probably late Ptolemaic", from the North-west mound, mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 79 § 79 and not the "green glazed monkey from chamber 29" (ibid., p. 74 § 72 ).
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 74 § 72, p. 79 § 79) (?)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.40, p.45, p.63, p.180, pl.22)
